articles.title: Rail fares to be frozen in England next year
articles.summary: Regulated fares, which include season tickets and off-peak returns, will not see annual price rises for the first time in 30 years, the government announces.
articles.content:
Rail fares to be frozen in England next year

Rail fares traditionally have gone up in January, based on the July rate of the retail price index (RPI) + 1% - although this formula has not always been followed.

The most recent fare rise, in March 2025, was 4.6%.

The freeze until March 2027 will apply to regulated fares, which includes season tickets and off-peak returns.

Rail fares in England next year are to be frozen for the first time in 30 years, the government has announced.

The announcement comes days before the chancellor sets out the government's financial plans in the Budget, amid a focus on the cost of living.

The government also said the move is intended to "directly limit inflation" by holding down "a major component of everyday costs".

Since 2021, the annual increase has come in March instead of January.

A government source acknowledged it was possible unregulated fares would still rise, but insisted they usually followed regulated fares.

Unregulated fares increased by 5.5% in the year to March 2025, 1.1% above regulated fares - with a total increase in rail fares of 5.1% in that period.

The Rail Delivery Group, a representative body made up of the UK's rail operators, said the freeze would be "good news for customers".

"We want our railways to thrive, that's why we're committed to working with government to ensure upcoming railway reforms deliver real benefits for customers," a spokesperson said.

Since 1996, the government has regulated some train fares following the privatisation of British Rail.

The freeze marks the first point since then that fares will have been frozen, although there have been periods where price increases were below RPI, and a dip in prices following the financial crash in 2010.

About 45% of rail fares are regulated by the government in England, Wales and Scotland - but the freeze only relates to travel in England. The announcement also only applies to services run by England-based train operating companies.

Regulated fares include season tickets covering most commuter routes, some off-peak return tickets on long-distance journeys and flexible tickets for travel in and around major cities.

Train operators are free to set prices for unregulated fares, but they typically rise by similar amounts.

The government estimates that the move will save commuters on more expensive routes more than £300.

Chancellor Rachel Reeves said the freeze was being put in place to help ease cost of living pressures, and make "travelling to work, school or to visit friends and family that bit easier".

Transport Secretary Heidi Alexander said it was part of "wider plans to rebuild Great British Railways".

Great British Railways is a public body which is in the process of being set up, and is part of the government's plans to bring parts of the railway system into public ownership.

The government has said it will take over the running and management of the tracks and trains, "ending years of fragmentation, driving up standards for passengers, and making journey easier and better value for money".

The government has said part of its plans for the new body is to "gradually move away from annual blanket increases".

Labour said passengers had faced "relentless" fare increases every year under the previous Tory government.

However, shadow transport secretary Richard Holden said: "In government, the Conservatives kept fares on the right track with below-inflation rises and consistently called for no further hikes to protect hard-working commuters."
articles.reasoning: The government’s decision to freeze regulated rail fares in England for the first time in 30 years represents a significant positive impact on the cost of living for a broad segment of the population, especially commuters. This policy change directly benefits millions of people by limiting transport expenses, which is a major component of everyday costs. The article provides sufficient context about the scope, historical background, and expected benefits of the fare freeze, making it a substantive and meaningful story with broad societal relevance.
articles.personality_title: England to freeze regulated rail fares for first time in 30 years
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Every year, rail fares in England usually go up in March, based on inflation plus a small extra amount. This has been the pattern for about 30 years, with prices rising steadily, making travel more expensive for many people.

**What happened** – The government announced that rail fares in England will not increase next year. This freeze applies to regulated fares, like season tickets and off-peak return tickets, which cover about 45% of rail travel. The freeze will last until March 2027, meaning prices for these tickets will stay the same for nearly two years.

**Impact** – This is the first time in three decades that regulated rail fares will not rise. It will help commuters and travelers save money, especially those who use season tickets for daily travel. The government estimates that people on more expensive routes could save over £300. Since transport costs are a big part of everyday expenses, this freeze can ease financial pressure for many households.

**What's next step** – The government is setting up a new public body called Great British Railways to manage tracks and trains more directly. They plan to reduce regular fare increases in the future and improve rail services. While unregulated fares might still go up, they usually follow the pattern of regulated fares, so this freeze might also influence those prices.

**One-sentence takeaway** – For the first time in 30 years, England will keep key rail ticket prices steady, helping commuters save money and easing living costs.
articles.personality_title_fr: Gel des tarifs ferroviaires réglementés en Angleterre pour la première fois en 30 ans
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Chaque année, les tarifs des trains en Angleterre augmentent généralement en mars, selon l'inflation plus un petit pourcentage. Cela dure depuis environ 30 ans, rendant les voyages plus chers pour beaucoup de monde.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Le gouvernement a annoncé qu'il n'y aura pas d'augmentation des tarifs ferroviaires réglementés en Angleterre l'année prochaine. Ce gel concerne les billets réglementés, comme les abonnements et les billets aller-retour hors heures de pointe, qui représentent environ 45 % des voyages en train. Ce gel durera jusqu'en mars 2027, donc les prix resteront les mêmes pendant presque deux ans.

**Impact** – C'est la première fois en trente ans que les tarifs réglementés ne vont pas augmenter. Cela aidera les voyageurs et les pendulaires à économiser de l'argent, surtout ceux qui utilisent des abonnements pour leurs trajets quotidiens. Le gouvernement estime que les personnes sur les trajets les plus chers pourraient économiser plus de 300 £. Comme les coûts de transport représentent une grande partie des dépenses quotidiennes, ce gel peut alléger la pression financière pour beaucoup de foyers.

**Prochaine étape** – Le gouvernement crée un nouvel organisme public appelé Great British Railways pour gérer directement les voies et les trains. Ils prévoient de réduire les augmentations régulières des tarifs à l'avenir et d'améliorer les services ferroviaires. Bien que les tarifs non réglementés puissent encore augmenter, ils suivent généralement la tendance des tarifs réglementés, donc ce gel pourrait aussi influencer ces prix.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Pour la première fois en 30 ans, l'Angleterre maintiendra les prix clés des billets de train stables, aidant les pendulaires à économiser et à réduire le coût de la vie.
articles.personality_title_es: Inglaterra congela tarifas ferroviarias reguladas por primera vez en 30 años
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Cada año, las tarifas de tren en Inglaterra suelen subir en marzo, basadas en la inflación más un pequeño porcentaje. Esto ha ocurrido durante unos 30 años, haciendo que viajar sea más caro para mucha gente.

**Qué pasó** – El gobierno anunció que las tarifas ferroviarias reguladas en Inglaterra no subirán el próximo año. Esta congelación afecta a los boletos regulados, como los abonos de temporada y los billetes de regreso fuera de las horas pico, que representan alrededor del 45 % de los viajes en tren. La congelación durará hasta marzo de 2027, por lo que los precios se mantendrán igual durante casi dos años.

**Impacto** – Es la primera vez en treinta años que las tarifas reguladas no aumentan. Esto ayudará a los viajeros y a quienes usan el tren diariamente a ahorrar dinero, especialmente a los que tienen abonos para sus viajes diarios. El gobierno estima que las personas en rutas más caras podrían ahorrar más de £300. Como los costos de transporte son una parte importante de los gastos diarios, esta congelación puede aliviar la presión financiera para muchas familias.

**Próximo paso** – El gobierno está creando un nuevo organismo público llamado Great British Railways para gestionar directamente las vías y los trenes. Planean reducir los aumentos regulares de tarifas en el futuro y mejorar los servicios ferroviarios. Aunque las tarifas no reguladas podrían subir, normalmente siguen el patrón de las tarifas reguladas, por lo que esta congelación podría influir también en esos precios.

**Frase clave** – Por primera vez en 30 años, Inglaterra mantendrá estables los precios clave de los billetes de tren, ayudando a los viajeros a ahorrar dinero y a reducir el costo de vida.
